trans-unit.source: Azure AD Windows Store Getting Started | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Windows Store Getting Started | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a Windows Store application that integrates with Azure AD for sign in and calls Azure AD protected APIs using OAuth.
trans-unit.target: How to build a Windows Store application that integrates with Azure AD for sign in and calls Azure AD protected APIs using OAuth.

trans-unit.source: If you're developing an app for the Windows Store, Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward for you to authenticate your users with their Active Directory accounts.
trans-unit.target: If you're developing an app for the Windows Store, Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward for you to authenticate your users with their Active Directory accounts.

trans-unit.source: It also enables your application to securely consume any web API protected by Azure AD, such as the Office 365 APIs or the Azure API.
trans-unit.target: It also enables your application to securely consume any web API protected by Azure AD, such as the Office 365 APIs or the Azure API.

trans-unit.source: For Windows Store desktop apps that need to access protected resources, Azure AD provides the Active Directory Authentication Library, or ADAL.
trans-unit.target: For Windows Store desktop apps that need to access protected resources, Azure AD provides the Active Directory Authentication Library, or ADAL.

trans-unit.source: ADAL’s sole purpose in life is to make it easy for your app to get access tokens.
trans-unit.target: ADAL’s sole purpose in life is to make it easy for your app to get access tokens.

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate just how easy it is, here we’ll build a "Directory Searcher" Windows Store app that:
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate just how easy it is, here we’ll build a "Directory Searcher" Windows Store app that:

trans-unit.source: Gets access tokens for calling the Azure AD Graph API using the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 authentication protocol</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Gets access tokens for calling the Azure AD Graph API using the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 authentication protocol</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Searches a directory for users with a given UPN.
trans-unit.target: Searches a directory for users with a given UPN.

trans-unit.source: Signs users out.
trans-unit.target: Signs users out.

trans-unit.source: To build the complete working application, you’ll need to:
trans-unit.target: To build the complete working application, you’ll need to:

trans-unit.source: Register your application with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Register your application with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Install & Configure ADAL.
trans-unit.target: Install & Configure ADAL.

trans-unit.source: Use ADAL to get tokens from Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Use ADAL to get tokens from Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: To get started, <linkText>download a skeleton project</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To get started, <linkText>download a skeleton project</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Each is a Visual Studio 2013 solution.
trans-unit.target: Each is a Visual Studio 2013 solution.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which you can create users and register an application.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which you can create users and register an application.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have a tenant, <linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have a tenant, <linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To enable your app to get tokens, you’ll first need to register it in your Azure AD tenant and grant it permission to access the Azure AD Graph API:
trans-unit.target: To enable your app to get tokens, you’ll first need to register it in your Azure AD tenant and grant it permission to access the Azure AD Graph API:

trans-unit.source: Sign into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Sign into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory
trans-unit.target: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Select a tenant in which to register the application.
trans-unit.target: Select a tenant in which to register the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the Applications tab, and click Add in the bottom drawer.
trans-unit.target: Click the Applications tab, and click Add in the bottom drawer.

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts and create a new Native Client Application.
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts and create a new Native Client Application.

trans-unit.source: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users
trans-unit.target: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users

trans-unit.source: The Redirect Uri is a scheme and string combination that Azure AD will use to return token responses.
trans-unit.target: The Redirect Uri is a scheme and string combination that Azure AD will use to return token responses.

trans-unit.source: Enter a placeholder value for now, e.g. http://DirectorySearcher.
trans-unit.target: Enter a placeholder value for now, e.g. http://DirectorySearcher.

trans-unit.source: We'll replace this value later.
trans-unit.target: We'll replace this value later.

trans-unit.source: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.
trans-unit.target: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need this value in the next sections, so copy it from the Configure tab.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need this value in the next sections, so copy it from the Configure tab.

trans-unit.source: Also in Configure tab, locate the "Permissions to Other Applications" section.
trans-unit.target: Also in Configure tab, locate the "Permissions to Other Applications" section.

trans-unit.source: For the "Azure Active Directory" application, add the Access Your Organization's Directory permission under Delegated Permissions.
trans-unit.target: For the "Azure Active Directory" application, add the Access Your Organization's Directory permission under Delegated Permissions.

trans-unit.source: This will enable your application to query the Graph API for users.
trans-unit.target: This will enable your application to query the Graph API for users.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have an application in Azure AD, you can install ADAL and write your identity-related code.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have an application in Azure AD, you can install ADAL and write your identity-related code.

trans-unit.source: In order for ADAL to be able to communicate with Azure AD, you need to provide it with some information about your app registration.
trans-unit.target: In order for ADAL to be able to communicate with Azure AD, you need to provide it with some information about your app registration.

trans-unit.source: Begin by adding ADAL to the DirectorySearcher project using the Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: Begin by adding ADAL to the DirectorySearcher project using the Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: In the DirectorySearcher project, open MainPage.xaml.cs.
trans-unit.target: In the DirectorySearcher project, open MainPage.xaml.cs.

trans-unit.source: Replace the values in the Config Values region to reflect the values you input into the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Replace the values in the Config Values region to reflect the values you input into the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Your code will reference these values whenever it uses ADAL.
trans-unit.target: Your code will reference these values whenever it uses ADAL.

trans-unit.source: The tenant is the domain of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. contoso.onmicrosoft.com
trans-unit.target: The tenant is the domain of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. contoso.onmicrosoft.com

trans-unit.source: The clientId is the clientId of your application you copied from the portal.
trans-unit.target: The clientId is the clientId of your application you copied from the portal.

trans-unit.source: You now need to discover the callback uri for your Windows Phone app.
trans-unit.target: You now need to discover the callback uri for your Windows Phone app.

trans-unit.source: Set a breakpoint on this line in the MainPage method:
trans-unit.target: Set a breakpoint on this line in the MainPage method:

trans-unit.source: Run the app, and copy aside the value of redirectUri when the breakpoint is hit.
trans-unit.target: Run the app, and copy aside the value of redirectUri when the breakpoint is hit.

trans-unit.source: It should look something like
trans-unit.target: It should look something like

trans-unit.source: Back on the Configure tab of your application in the Azure Management Portal, replace the value of the RedirectUri with this value.
trans-unit.target: Back on the Configure tab of your application in the Azure Management Portal, replace the value of the RedirectUri with this value.

trans-unit.source: The basic principle behind ADAL is that whenever your app needs an access token, it simply calls authContext.AcquireToken(…), and ADAL does the rest.
trans-unit.target: The basic principle behind ADAL is that whenever your app needs an access token, it simply calls authContext.AcquireToken(…), and ADAL does the rest.

trans-unit.source: The first step is to initialize your app’s AuthenticationContext - ADAL’s primary class.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to initialize your app’s AuthenticationContext - ADAL’s primary class.

trans-unit.source: This is where you pass ADAL the coordinates it needs to communicate with Azure AD and tell it how to cache tokens.
trans-unit.target: This is where you pass ADAL the coordinates it needs to communicate with Azure AD and tell it how to cache tokens.

trans-unit.source: Now locate the Search(...) method, which will be invoked when the user cliks the "Search" button in the app's UI.
trans-unit.target: Now locate the Search(...) method, which will be invoked when the user cliks the "Search" button in the app's UI.

trans-unit.source: This method makes a GET request to the Azure AD Graph API to query for users whose UPN begins with the given search term.
trans-unit.target: This method makes a GET request to the Azure AD Graph API to query for users whose UPN begins with the given search term.

trans-unit.source: But in order to query the Graph API, you need to include an access_token in the Authorization header of the request - this is where ADAL comes in.
trans-unit.target: But in order to query the Graph API, you need to include an access_token in the Authorization header of the request - this is where ADAL comes in.

trans-unit.source: When your app requests a token by calling AcquireTokenAsync(...), ADAL will attempt to return a token without asking the user for credentials.
trans-unit.target: When your app requests a token by calling AcquireTokenAsync(...), ADAL will attempt to return a token without asking the user for credentials.

trans-unit.source: If ADAL determines that the user needs to sign in to get a token, it will display a login dialog, collect the user's credentials, and return a token upon successful authentication.
trans-unit.target: If ADAL determines that the user needs to sign in to get a token, it will display a login dialog, collect the user's credentials, and return a token upon successful authentication.

trans-unit.source: If ADAL is unable to return a token for any reason, the AuthenticationResult status will be an error.
trans-unit.target: If ADAL is unable to return a token for any reason, the AuthenticationResult status will be an error.

trans-unit.source: Now it's time to use the the access_token you just acquired.
trans-unit.target: Now it's time to use the the access_token you just acquired.

trans-unit.source: Also in the Search(...) method, attach the token to the Graph API GET request in the Authorization header:
trans-unit.target: Also in the Search(...) method, attach the token to the Graph API GET request in the Authorization header:

trans-unit.source: You can also use the AuthenticationResult object to display information about the user in your app, such as the user's id:
trans-unit.target: You can also use the AuthenticationResult object to display information about the user in your app, such as the user's id:

trans-unit.source: Finally, you can use ADAL to sign the user out of the application as well.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you can use ADAL to sign the user out of the application as well.

trans-unit.source: When the user clicks the "Sign Out" button, we want to ensure that the next call to AcquireTokenAsync(...) will show a sign in view.
trans-unit.target: When the user clicks the "Sign Out" button, we want to ensure that the next call to AcquireTokenAsync(...) will show a sign in view.

trans-unit.source: With ADAL, this is as easy as clearing the token cache:
trans-unit.target: With ADAL, this is as easy as clearing the token cache:

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: You now have a working Windows Store app that has the ability to authenticate users, securely call Web APIs using OAuth 2.0, and get basic information about the user.
trans-unit.target: You now have a working Windows Store app that has the ability to authenticate users, securely call Web APIs using OAuth 2.0, and get basic information about the user.

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already, now is the time to populate your tenant with some users.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already, now is the time to populate your tenant with some users.

trans-unit.source: Run your DirectorySearcher app, and sign in with one of those users.
trans-unit.target: Run your DirectorySearcher app, and sign in with one of those users.

trans-unit.source: Search for other users based on their UPN.
trans-unit.target: Search for other users based on their UPN.

trans-unit.source: Close the app, and re-run it.
trans-unit.target: Close the app, and re-run it.

trans-unit.source: Notice how the user’s session remains intact.
trans-unit.target: Notice how the user’s session remains intact.

trans-unit.source: Sign out (by right-clicking to show the bottom bar), and sign back in as another user.
trans-unit.target: Sign out (by right-clicking to show the bottom bar), and sign back in as another user.

trans-unit.source: ADAL makes it easy to incorporate all of these common identity features into your application.
trans-unit.target: ADAL makes it easy to incorporate all of these common identity features into your application.

trans-unit.source: It takes care of all the dirty work for you - cache management, OAuth protocol support, presenting the user with a login UI, refreshing expired tokens, and more.
trans-unit.target: It takes care of all the dirty work for you - cache management, OAuth protocol support, presenting the user with a login UI, refreshing expired tokens, and more.

trans-unit.source: All you really need to know is a single API call, authContext.AcquireToken*(…).
trans-unit.target: All you really need to know is a single API call, authContext.AcquireToken*(…).

trans-unit.source: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can now move on to additional identity scenarios.
trans-unit.target: You can now move on to additional identity scenarios.

trans-unit.source: You may want to try:
trans-unit.target: You may want to try:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Secure a .NET Web API with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Secure a .NET Web API with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title>
